At Fri, 11 Jan 2008 17:40:59 -0000,
"dyamblor" <fredlicious34@...> wrote:
>
> Is arcreader supposed to return the offset of the URL record (ex.
> http://www.dryswamp.edu:80/index.html 127.10.100.2 19961104142103
> text/html 202) or the first line of the header (ex.  HTTP/1.0 200
> Document follows)?
>
> When you use the output of arcreader to read the file from the offset
> it  gives, the offset starts at the beginning of the URL record line.
> If you read the exact size of the file that arcreader returns,
> beginning at the offset it returns, it cuts off the end of the file by
> exactly the length of the URL record line (the first line).
>
> Is that how it is supposed to work?

Yes.

The offset is the position in the file where the header starts. The
header is of indeterminate length: you will not know its size until
you read it. The size listed in the header is the size of the record
that follows the linefeed which terminates the header.

So in order to read a record, you need to skip to the offset, then
read to the end of the header (the first linefeed), then read the size
in bytes given in the header, and then, finally, read an extra
linefeed which terminates the record.

best,
Erik Hetzner
;; Erik Hetzner, California Digital Library
;; gnupg key id: 1024D/01DB07E3
